Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Novel QM/MM algorithms for understanding efficient energy harvesting in photosynthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Lyudmila Slipchenko of Purdue University is supported by an award from the Theory, Models and Computational Method program to develop computational methods that enable accurate and predictive modeling of energy transfer in natural and artificial photosynthetic complexes, including explicit solvent effects of the protein environment. The methods are based on the quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) approach in which accurate excited state methods are used for the QM part and the ab initio-based effective fragment potential (EFP) method is used for the MM part. The EFP method overcomes the most significant limitation of existing QM/MM techniques by replacing empirical interactions by parameter-free first principles based terms, without a sacrifice in computational efficiency.

The PI and her research group are developing computational tools that enable accurate and predictive modeling of energy transfer in natural and artificial photosynthetic complexes, including the explicit effect of the protein environment. This research increases our understanding of energy harvesting and contributes to the engineering of efficient photovoltaic devices and photosynthetic systems. This research has a strong component of computer code design. The resulting software is integrated into widely used quantum chemistry codes and made available to the broad community of scientists and engineers.

This research is supported in a co-funding arrangement with the Office of Cyberinfrastruture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solar radiation is the biggest energy source available for utilization by human society; it exceeds the overall energy consumption in the world by a factor of ~104. Over millions of years photosynthetic plants and bacteria developed supreme mechanisms of solar energy harvesting (with efficiencies often exceeding 95%) and photoprotection. Plants absorb solar light using chlorophylls, which are pigment molecules of photosynthetic proteins stored in plant chloroplasts. However, before the energy of the absorbed photons can be utilized, it is transferred over a significant distance to so-called reaction centers that convert the potential energy of excited electrons into chemical energy. While this long-distance transfer of excitation energy works flawlessly in plants and bacteria, it remains one of the principal bottlenecks in design of efficient solar cells. Thus, an understanding of mechanisms of excitation energy transfer in plants holds the key to engineering efficient solar devices and solving the world’s energy problem.

It is clear that the excitation energy transfer in plants is ensured by the specific structure of photosynthetic proteins. The role of the protein is two-fold. First, the protein creates a structural cage that keeps chlorophylls in a particular arrangement optimal for directed energy transfer. Additionally, light-absorbing properties of chlorophylls are affected by the local environment created by a sequence of protein amino acid residues. Altogether, the photosynthetic proteins are responsible for a directional energy transfer toward a desired location (reaction center), similar to how one could control direction and intensity of water flow by adjusting a local landscape. However, a detailed mechanistic picture of how the photosynthetic proteins control excitation energy transfer remains elusive. In this project we developed computational methods that allow comprehensive analysis and characterization of structure-function relations in photosynthetic complexes.

 

Intellectual merit

We considered two aspects of the protein role on energy transfer: the effect of the particular arrangement of chlorophylls, and the effect of a local protein environment on light-absorbing properties of each chlorophyll. Toward the first goal, we developed a model that predicts energies of a complex system, i.e., a system containing several pigments, based on their relative orientation in space and vibrational motion. We validated this vibronic coupling model on flexible molecules containing two chromophores, using high-resolution experimental data as a reference. Toward the second goal, we developed a model that allows for a rigorous description of the protein environment on the light-absorbing properties of chromophores. The complexity here is that at present it is not feasible to accurately describe the whole protein using quantum mechanical (QM) methods, even using the most powerful supercomputers. Instead, one can use an approximated approach, in which only a small part of the protein is represented quantum-mechanically. In the remainder of the protein, atoms are described with classical (molecular) mechanics (MM), using a ball-and-spring model. Such hybrid quantum-classical (QM/MM) models have an advantage over fully quantum modeling by dramatically reducing computational cost, while the important aspects of protein chemistry, such as electronic excitations and energy transfer, can be captured. However, despite many appealing features of hybrid models, there are significant concerns due to disconnect of quantum and classical representations, and as a consequence, a loss of accuracy in describing protein properties. In this project we developed and validated a new hybrid model that, while being computationally efficient, provides a meticulous coupling between quantum and classical subsystems.
